greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of (unordered) ways of writing 2n+1 as a sum of 3 odd primes.
comment: Ways of writing 2n+1 as p+q+r where p,q,r are odd primes with p <= q <= r.

The two papers of Helfgott appear to provide a proof of the Odd Goldbach Conjecture that every odd number greater than five is the sum of three primes. (The paper is still being reviewed.) - _Peter Luschny_, May 18 2013; _N. J. A. Sloane_, May 19 2013
reference: George E. Andrews, Number Theory (NY, Dover, 1994), page 111.
Ivars Peterson, The Mathematical Tourist (NY, W. H. Freeman, 1998, pages 35-37.
Paulo Ribenboim, "VI, Goldbach's famous conjecture," The New Book of Prime Number Records, 3rd ed. (NY, Springer, 1996), pages 291-299.
link: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
H. A. Helfgott, Minor arcs for Goldbach's problem, arXiv:1205.5252 [math.NT], 2012.
H. A. Helfgott, Major arcs for Goldbach's theorem, arXiv:1305.2897 [math.NT], 2013.
H. A. Helfgott, The ternary Goldbach conjecture is true, arxiv:1312.7748 [math.NT], 2013.
H. A. Helfgott, The ternary Goldbach problem, arXiv:1404.2224 [math.NT], 2014.
Index entries for sequences related to Goldbach conjecture
mathematica: nn = 75; ps = Prime[Range[2, nn + 1]]; c = Flatten[Table[If[i >= j >= k, i + j + k, 0], {i, ps}, {j, ps}, {k, ps}]]; Join[{0, 0, 0, 0}, Transpose[Take[Rest[Sort[Tally[c]]], nn+2]][[2]]] (* _T. D. Noe_, Apr 08 2014 *)
program: (Perl) use ntheory ":all"; sub a007963 { my($n,$c)=(shift,0); forpart { $c++ if vecall { is_prime($_) } @_; } $n,{n=>3,amin=>3}; $c; }
(PARI) a(n)=my(k=2*n+1,s,t); forprime(p=(k+2)\3,k-6, t=k-p; forprime(q=t\2,min(t-3,p), if(isprime(t-q), s++))); s \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Mar 20 2017
xref: Cf. A068307, A087916, A294294 (lower bound of scatterplot), A294357, A294358 (records).
results.author: R. Muller
